ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
theoretical and conceptual appreciation of the debate about the movements of the extreme right.

An international approach to political science. 

ability to write concisely about complex topics on the extreme right.
An analytical toolkit for examining the extreme and radical right.
I developed greater insight into the concept of the far right and how it manifests itself in different settings throughout time and place.
This class is a valuable exploration into difficult subjects, which are rarely but also best address in an academic setting. Should be taken by anyone interested in political science!

A great class if you're interested in political theory as well as contemporary events-- you'll learn a lot of foundational stuff about authoritarianism, nationalism, the far right, and theories of participation as well as a lot of more specific dives into contemporary cases and testimonies. I think out of the many political science classes I've taken, I learned the most from discussions in this class. You'll definitely get back whatever you choose to put in (if not more, honestly). Take it!
I learned a lot about extreme-right movements in the US and around the world. I also gained writing skills.

In Extreme and Radical Right Movements I learned how the extreme right manifests itself in a variety of contexts across the globe. The seminar helped me to understand unifying ideological traits of the extreme right as well as how and why people become affiliated with extreme right movements. Our readings were highly informative and our meeting discussions were very helpful in providing different perspectives on how to combat the extreme right.
I learned a lot about far right movements and how they work and about theories of fascism and nationalism.

A better understanding of the extreme right-- both in a practical sense (reading about current events, watching interviews from former/current members of fascist movements, etc.), and in the theoretical sense (reading about casual theories, discussing the predecessors and historical context for right movements, etc.). As someone on the left, I felt as though I came out of the course with better skills regarding interacting with people on the right, which is often neglected at places like Yale. I also highly enjoyed hearing from my peers during the discussion section of the course, and adding their ideas, thoughts on readings, and personal experience to my collection of knowledge from this course.
I learned a lot about the motives and theories of support for the extreme right, which have more complex and surprising layers than the media shows.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: use of videos, good readings, conversations facilitation, challenging but engaging writing assignments.

weaknesses: difficulty of flowing conversations over zoom
The readings were very engaging and I enjoyed the structure (with a short lecture followed by a lengthy discussion).

The class is quite interesting and the readings are always applicable. I also enjoyed how Prof. Aslanidis weaved in our response papers into the lesson plans for each class themselves so it made doing those papers feel a bit more meaningful.

This was really a fantastic class generally. Prof. Aslanidis relies on a variety of media (academic and non-academic, like movies and manifestos) to expose students to the interstices of far-right ideology and practice.

Paris is a huge strength of the course, he's an excellent professor who will really engage with your ideas in class and in any of your writing. Also, the class is usually a mix of discussion, short screenings, and a very short topical lecture--you'll stay interested.
Strengths: The content of this class is really interesting. The response paper prompts were good, the discussions were interesting and well-paced

Extreme and Radical Right Movements did a very good job of integrating Professor Aslanidis's insights and media about the extreme right into peer-based discussion on the subject. The readings were generally highly informative and intriguing. The response papers helped me to develop an understanding of different aspects of the extreme right, and the final paper helped me to apply the knowledge I gained from this seminar to a specific area of personal interest.

My only critique would be that a couple of the readings felt more like political philosophy than direct perspectives on the extreme right, and I found these texts very difficult to comprehend.

I really loved this course! It was over half women and is only of the only PLSC seminars where I felt very little trouble unmuting to speak! Professor Aslanidis also really helps make sure to call on students and not let people speak over each other which made it easier to speak. I really loved this course and also appreciated how reasonable the readings and assignments were!

I have all good things to say about this course. I really enjoyed the readings and discussion, and the course content is incredibly interesting in itself. Oftentimes, Yale courses use 'clickbait'-y titles that sound wildly compelling, only to devolve into outdated and confusing readings that focus an entirely different topic entirely; Extreme Radical Right was NOT an example of this. I consistently felt excited about the units and coursework, and Paris intentionally included up-to-date readings and opportunities to discuss current events and personal experiences in class.

Professor Aslanidis does a great job of compiling provocative video clips and interesting news articles for class. I really liked how the readings were varied and not too academic-heavy (for example, one week we read the actual manifesto written by white nationalist mass murderers, which was super interesting). The course's quirky topic naturally made class discussions engaging, and the workload was fair. No significant weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
succeeded: watching and discusssing videos about the extreme right in class

improved: conversations facilitation over zoom.
The course was a success!
Paris did a really good job of integrating clips and visuals into the class, which made it more interactive than a solely Zoom conversation.
We watched videos in class sometimes which were a good break from the discussion, but still engaging.
Extreme and Radical Right Movements effectively integrated brief media clips about the extreme right into our peer-based discussions. This helped to spur conversation and engagement.
Calling on people to speak in seminar instead of having people speak over each other!

This course is the best example of positive and engaging online learning I've had at Yale thus far. Every class was broken up into different parts to keep us guessing; sometimes Paris would share a few video clips in between discussion, to provide more perspective on the readings, and allow us to take a break from the big block of time allotted for the seminar. Additionally, discussion was always active in the class, and at times Paris encouraged us to use the chat feature (during video clips especially) to have another layer of engagement.
The entire course was a virtual seminar format, so the level of live engagement was high. Given the circumstances, I think the course was well-organized.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. It is extremely engaging and takes an international perspective on a very important issue. Great assignments and Professor Aslandis is great.
Yes, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Yes! I think Prof. Aslanidis is really passionate about the topic and the combination of readings, documentaries, and other mediums really allows you to get  a comprehensive view of a very timely and relevant social movement.
Definitely! A great course with a committed professor that focuses on subject which are difficult but essential to be exposed to.

Absolutely, this was one of my favorite classes during my time here, partially because the things we discussed and questions we asked in class always felt very timely and meaningful, and more so because of the way the course is kept interesting and fast-paced. If you're down to engage with some of the more heavy, theoretical arguments and do a bit of reading every week then you should definitely take the class.
Yes, I would, I think that the format of the class was good. Each week was a different topic and they all linked together well and were interesting.
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in learning about the extreme right in both a domestic and international context.
Yes! I really loved this course :)

Yes! Great professor, engaging course content, and writing assignments with topics that are actually fun to write. Especially if you identify as somewhere on the left, and come from a community of somewhat like-minded people, I would highly recommend taking the opportunity to educate yourself on the other side, the dangers it poses, and the ways in which we can combat extreme right movements.
Yes I'd recommend. Awesome professor and very interesting course topic.

comments: N/A
